keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter, was arrested on a charge of threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries, a U.S. House Minority Leader.
Moynihan was previously convicted of obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct during the January 6 Capitol attack and sentenced to nearly two years in prison.
President Donald Trump pardoned Moynihan earlier in 2025 as part of a broader pardon of January 6 defendants.
Moynihan allegedly made text messages threatening to kill Jeffries, stating he would eliminate him 'for the future' and that Jeffries was a 'terrorist'.
New York authorities suspect Moynihan of drug abuse and increased homicidal ideation, citing an anonymous source to the FBI.
A New York judge has ordered Moynihan to remain in prison while awaiting a hearing on whether he can be released pending trial on terroristic threat charges.
No attorneys are listed for Moynihan in the New York case, and family members have not been reached.
The case reflects broader concerns about political violence and threats against public officials in the wake of high-profile assassinations, such as that of Charlie Kirk.
Prior to the Capitol incident, Moynihan had shown political engagement during the Trump administration, spending time consuming political content online.
Moynihan’s attorneys previously requested mental health and addiction treatment during sentencing, citing a history of opiate addiction and prior substance-related convictions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a man previously convicted of participating in the January 6 Capitol attack, was arrested in October 2025 on a charge of making a terroristic threat against Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Moynihan allegedly threatened to kill Jeffries in a text message, claiming he would eliminate him 'for the future' due to political opposition. Despite being pardoned by President Donald Trump earlier in 2025, Moynihan remains incarcerated pending a trial on the threat charge. Authorities have cited signs of drug abuse and increased homicidal ideation, with Moynihan’s attorneys having previously requested mental health and addiction treatment during sentencing. The case underscores growing concerns about political violence and threats against public officials, especially in the wake of high-profile assassinations such as that of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk. Moynihan’s actions and legal status reflect ongoing tensions between political extremism, justice, and public safety.
